intro: Carex atrofusca var. fulvicoma, commonly known as black sedge, is a perennial plant native to parts of North America. It is a member of the Cyperaceae family, characterized by its grass-like appearance and spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in moist to wet habitats such as swamps, marshes, and along stream banks. Its dark green, strap-like leaves are arranged in dense tufts, and it produces small, inconspicuous brown flowers in early summer. The variety fulvicoma is distinguished by its yellowish-brown stems and is often found in coastal areas.
